thread.title: No Zuma influence?

author: news24.com
title: No Zuma influence?
text:
No sooner had the new Chairperson of the Independent Electoral Commission been appointed and questions were asked and started pouring in.
Mr Glen Mashinini previously served as special projects adviser to President Jacob Zuma and this was the basis of the opposition’s outcry over his appointment.
Mr Mashinini is replacing advocate Pansy Tlakula, who was the commissioner and chairperson before she resigned in September 2014 after the EFF and other opposition parties approached the Electoral Court, seeking an order for her resignation.
This seeking of such order was after the Public Protector Thuli Madonsela in August 2013 found that Tlakula had flouted procurement procedures in securing an R320m lease for the IEC’s new head office building in Centurion.
At the time a forensic audit by the national treasury also found that the procurement process was neither fair and transparent, nor cost-effective.
President Jacob Zuma on Wednesday announced the appointment of Mr Mashinini and the forces behind it now claims that “the due process was headed by the chief justice that came to the conclusion to recommend Mashinini’s appointment.”
Mashinini furthermore claims that he has “served internationally in elections and that his appointment is a professional responsibility that he is comfortable with”
The strategic importance of appointing the right person for the job cannot be underestimated. He or she has to restore the image and credibility of the IEC from the dented image that Tlakula opposed on it.
But the main question to be asked is if Mashinini would really be unbiased, come any future elections, this after having been so close to Zuma’s inner circle.
Elections has to be free, fair and without intimidation, fault or favour, but we can seriously wonder how and where the loyalty of Mr Mashinini would lie in future elections, and how his decision once elections is done and dusted can be ‘bought’?
That the ANC is desperate to have the right people in the right places, in view of its diminished support base and the upcoming local elections of 2016, is as clear as daylight.
And what better move to make than to put one of your closest allies in the position of Chairperson of the IEC just if it is ever needed to ‘alter’ those votes cast to be in favour of the man that you served closely and the party that you obviously support.
In time to come we will see that this appointment wasn’t made on the face of having someone transparent, loyal, unbiased and a-political person in the position, but for personal and party benefit, and then the consequences may bite us in the shin and for us then to realize that the appointment was made with a personal and party agenda behind it.
The ANC at this point in time is so desperate to secure its support come the 2016 elections and what better place than to have one of your own as Chairperson of the IEC?
